Title: Insula of the old world monkey. II: Afferent cortical input and comments on the claustrum
Abstract: " The afferent connections of the insula in the rhesus monkey were studied with axonal transport methods. Injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) in the insula revealed labeled neurons in the prefrontal cortex, the lateral orbital region, the frontoparietal operculum, the cingulate gyrus and adjacent medial cortex, the prepiriform olfactory cortex, the temporal pole, the cortex of the superior temporal sulcus, the rhinal cortex, the supratemporal plane, and the posterior parietal lobe. Tritiated amino acid (TAA) injections in some of the cortical regions which contained retrogradely labeled neurons confirmed projections to the insula from prefrontal granular cortex, orbital frontal cortex, prepiriform cortex, temporal pole, rhinal cortex, cingulate gyrus, frontal operculum, and parietal cortex. In these studies, cortical areas that projected to the insula also projected to the claustrum. However, the topographic and quantitative relationships between the projections into the insula and those into the claustrum were inconsistent. Moreover, the claustrum has additional connections which it does not share with the insula. A selected review of the literature suggests that the claustrum and insula differ widely also with respect to ontogenesis and functional specialization. "

@BrainMaps.Comments:
The architectonic subdivision of the insula and adajcent regions is adopted from MM82a: " The purpose of this paper...is to report our observations on the cortical afferents...of the old world monkey insula...Furthermore, the organization of these cortical connections will be analyzed with respect to the architectonic subdivisions of the insula which have been described elsewhere (Mesulam and Mufson, '82a )." ( p. 24 )
This is also reflected by the legends of the figures 1, 3-7: "These designations are based on Figure 1a of Mesulam and Mufson ('82a)."

MM82a, MM82b, and MM82c are companion papers by the same authors.
It seems likely that Mufson and Mesulam' s area 5 corresponds to Brodmann's ('05) area 5, because the authors chose this map for describing other parietal areas (e.g. areas 3, 1, 2).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "On the orbital surface HRP-filled neurons were seen surrounding the lateral limb of the medial orbital sulcus (MOS) in a region which corresponded to area 11 of Walker ('40).Further medially at the junction of the madial and lateral branches of the MOS an aggregate of labeled neurons was seen in Walker's area 13 (Walker, '40). These two regions correspond to the granular OFg sector of lateral orbital cortex (Mesulam and Mufson, '82a; Fig. 1, sections 1 and 2). In addition, a more laterally placed group of labeled neurons was found in dysgranular (OFdg) orbital cortex (Area 12 of Walker, '40) and more posteriorly in the agranular orbitofrontal sector (OFa-p of Mesulam anf Mufson('82a); Fig. 1, sections 3 and 4)." (p. 25) " There were labeled neurons in OFg (areas11, 12 and 13), in lateral OFdg( area 12), in OFa-p, as well as in the prefrontal granular cortex (area 46; Fig. 3, sections 1-7). " (p. 27)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
The text does not clear in which relation Walker's areas 11-13 are with Mesulam and Mufson's areas OFg and OFdg.
Only the companion paper MM82a gives a hint about the relation of these areas.

@Injections.Citation: "Tritiated amino acids (TAA) were injected in anterior TPdg with minor involvement of STPg (Fig. 5)." (p. 31)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
" Architectonic evaluation had revealed that the insula and the lateral orbitofrontal regions shared a similar organization plan
( Mesulam and Mufson 82`a ).
In order to determine if these two regions also shared connectivity patterns, we examined the orbital region in cases 1a-9a.
In each of these cases which contained insular TAA labeling there was also lateral orbitofrontal labeling.
In some of these cases, the anterograde TAA labeling occured within analogous architectonic sectors of the two regions.
For example. in Cases 1a and 9a where anterograde labeling was restricted primarily to Ia-p and Idg, labeling in the lateral orbital region was observed in OFa-p and OFdg.
In case 3a where insular labeling was mainly in Idg and Ig, orbital labeling was observed in OFdg and OFg.
These initial findings and similar ones with respect to insular efferents suggest that the insula and lateral orbital regions may have analogous distributions of afferent input. " ( p. 36 )

" The relationship between anterograde labeling in the insula and claustrum was evaluated in Cases 1a-9a.
In each of these nine TAA cases, label was observed not only in the insula but also in the claustrum.
However, it was not possible to determine if the claustral labeling occured in terminals within the extreme and external
capsules.
In some cases ( 1a-2a, 4a-6a ) ventral insular labeling was associated with ventral labeling in the claustrum.
However, in other cases this toographic relationship was far less evident.
Furthermore, the intensity of claustral labeling did not necessarily parrelel the intensity of insular labeling. " ( pp. 31-32 )

@Injections.Citation: "TAA was injected in the anterior cingulate gyrus (Fig. 5)." (p. 31)
@Injections.Comments: The cingulate gyrus was previously designated to consist of Brodmann's (1909) areas 24 and 23 (p. 29).

@Injections.Citation: " TAA was injected in the orbitofrontal cortex (OFa-p and OFdg; Fig. 6). " (p. 31)

@Injections.Comments: The entorhinal cortex was previously described (see p. 27) to consist of area 28 of Van Hoesen & Pandya (1975).

@Injections.Citation: " TAA was injected in the temporal portion of prepiriform olfactory cortex. Minimal extension of the injection site occured into TPa-p and into the endopyriform nucleus (Fig. 6)." (p. 31)
@Injections.Comments: List of abbreviations on p. 25: poc = prepiriform portion of olfactory cortex. Note that this injection site did also involve the endopyriform nucleus which is not listed here yet as an affected site.

@Injections.Citation: " TAA was injected in prefrontal granular cortex (including area 46) (Fig. 7). " (p. 31)
@Injections.Comments: Neither text nor Fig. 7 clearly state whether further prefrontal areas than area 46 were affected by this injection, thus making the interpretation of the results from this injection difficult.

@Methods_Animals.Comments: An explicit age is not mentioned; the only information is, that these animals were adolescents or adults.

@Methods.Comments:
Both free HRP and HRP conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin 
( HRP-WGA ) are used. As HRP-WGA is both a retrograde and anterograde tracer, it necessary to check carefully for each datum whether labeled cells or terminals are described.

@Injections.Citation: " The injection site was in the anterior insula (Figs. 1, sections 5-9, and 2A). It was centered predominantly in the most anterior parts of the agranular (Ia-p) and dysgranular (Idg) sectors of the insula. The halo of the injection site spread to the extreme capsule, the claustrum, the lateral border of the putamen, and insular limb of the prepiriform olfactory cortex (POC). The needle track did not extend into the extreme capsule. It appears that a narrow strip of dorsal temporal pole was included in the injection site (Fig. 1, sections 6-7). A substantial segment of parietal operculum and of the supratemporal plane was damaged during the surgical approach (Fig. 1, sections 7-11)." (p. 25)
@Injections.Comments: This injection was centered in the anterior insula.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
Although both HRP and HRP-WGA were used, only labeled neurons/perikarya were mentioned by the descriptions of the results.
The term neurons actually means perikarya and terminals, but often the term perikarya is added, so in my opinion it becomes clear, that the author means only perikarya.

@Injections.Citation: " The injection was focused primarily in the mid portion of Idg (Fig. 3, sections 7-10). Injectate spread to immediately adjacent portions of Ia-p and Idg. A halo of HRP reaction product was seen extending to the extreme capsule, the claustrum, and the lateral border of the putamen. There was no damage to the extreme capsule. In contrast to case A, there was no involvement of prepiriform olfactory cortex (POC) or STPg. There was less damage to the opercular and supratemporal regions during the surgical approach (Fig. 3, sections 8-11). With respect to the insular topography , the center of the injection was situated more posterior than in case A and did not involve the more extreme anterior portions of Ia-p or Idg. " (p. 27)
@Injections.Comments: This injection was centered in midanterior insula.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
Although both free HRP and HRP-WGA were used, only labeled neurons/ perikarya were mentioned in the descriptions of the results.
The term  neurons actually means perikarya and terminals, but often the term perikarya is added, so in my opinion it becomes clear, that the author means only perikarya.

@Injections.Citation: " The injection site was almost entirely within Ig with an extension into the most caudal part of Idg (Figs. 2B and 4, sections 7-9). A halo of reaction product extended to the extreme capsule, the claustrum, and the lateral border of the putamen. We also observed evidence for a possible spread of the injection site to both banks of the lateral fissure (Fig. 4, sections 8 and 9). In contrast to Cases A and B, the needle tract penetrated the extreme capsule. Portions of the opercular and the supratemporal plane were severely damaged during the surgical approach (Fig. 4, sections 7-10). " (p. 29)
@Injections.Comments: This injection was centered in the posterior insula. Damage to the extreme capsule by the needle tract may have falsified the results of this injection.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
Although both free HRP and HRP-WGA were used, only labeled neurons/ perikarya were mentioned in the descriptions of the results.
The term  neurons actually means perikarya and terminals, but often the term perikarya is added, so in my opinion it becomes clear, that the author means only perikarya.

@Methods_Animals.Comments: An explicit age is not mentioned; the only information is, that these animals were adolescents or adults.

publication.title: Insula of the old world monkey. II: Afferent cortical input and comments on the claustrum
publication.abstract: " The afferent connections of the insula in the rhesus monkey were studied with axonal transport methods. Injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) in the insula revealed labeled neurons in the prefrontal cortex, the lateral orbital region, the frontoparietal operculum, the cingulate gyrus and adjacent medial cortex, the prepiriform olfactory cortex, the temporal pole, the cortex of the superior temporal sulcus, the rhinal cortex, the supratemporal plane, and the posterior parietal lobe. Tritiated amino acid (TAA) injections in some of the cortical regions which contained retrogradely labeled neurons confirmed projections to the insula from prefrontal granular cortex, orbital frontal cortex, prepiriform cortex, temporal pole, rhinal cortex, cingulate gyrus, frontal operculum, and parietal cortex. In these studies, cortical areas that projected to the insula also projected to the claustrum. However, the topographic and quantitative relationships between the projections into the insula and those into the claustrum were inconsistent. Moreover, the claustrum has additional connections which it does not share with the insula. A selected review of the literature suggests that the claustrum and insula differ widely also with respect to ontogenesis and functional specialization. "
